biography.title: Biography of the Master
biography.description: Michael Thonet (1796-1871) was a German carpenter and industrialist who revolutionized furniture production by introducing innovative steam-bending wood technology.
biography.earlyYearsText: Born in Boppard on the Rhine, Michael Thonet began his career as a carpenter. From a young age, he was fascinated by the possibilities of giving wood new shapes.
biography.breakthroughText: In the 1830s, Thonet developed a revolutionary method of bending beech wood using steam, which enabled mass production of elegant furniture.

timeline.title: Life and Works Timeline
timeline.description: Key events in Michael Thonet's life and the development of his enterprise.

1796.title: Birth in Boppard
1796.description: Michael Thonet comes into the world in a small town on the Rhine, in a family with carpentry traditions.

1819.title: Beginning of Activity
1819.description: Establishment of his own carpentry workshop and first experiments with wood processing techniques.

1841.title: Move to Vienna
1841.description: At the invitation of Prince Metternich, Thonet moves his business to Vienna, where he receives better development conditions.

1850.title: Factory Establishment
1850.description: Creation of the company "Gebrüder Thonet" and beginning of mass production of bent wood furniture.

1859.title: Chair No. 14
1859.description: Introduction to the market of the famous Chair No. 14, which will become an icon of industrial design.

1871.title: Death of the Master
1871.description: Michael Thonet dies in Vienna, leaving behind an industrial empire and revolutionary heritage.

collection_section.title: Virtual Gallery of Paweł Michalski's Collection
collection_section.description: The furniture presented on the site comes from the private collection of a hobbyist and restorer from Radom. The exhibition at the Old Coach House in Lewków featured over 60 Thonet furniture pieces - from a cradle to a wardrobe.

chair_no_14.title: Chair No. 14 - Design Icon
chair_no_14.description: A famous model, well-known from many pop culture images, which the designer simply named '14'. Michael Thonet invented it in 1848. It is still produced today, in tens of millions of units. This chair initiated a style that continues to this day.
chair_no_14.notes: The restoration of this piece required strengthening the screw connections and recreating the original, hand-woven cane seat.

rocking_chair_no_10.title: Rocking Chair No. 10
rocking_chair_no_10.description: One of Thonet's most elegant and organic designs. Its flowing lines and innovative construction made it a favorite piece of furniture for many artists, including Pablo Picasso, Marilyn Monroe, and Liza Minnelli. Its form is still admired today.
rocking_chair_no_10.notes: The key challenge was to restore the perfect curvature of the runners, which had deformed over the years. Traditional steam-bending methods were used.
rocking_chair_no_10.image1_desc: [To this day, they remain a design icon and are highly valued on the antiques and collectibles market.]
rocking_chair_no_10.image2_desc: [They were particularly popular in bourgeois homes, sanatoriums, and cafes at the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries.]

a_811_armchair.title: Armchair A 811 (des. Josef Hoffmann)
a_811_armchair.description: A design attributed to Josef Hoffmann from the 1920s. It is characterized by its simple, geometric form and hand-woven backrest and seat, a hallmark of designs for Thonet from that period.
a_811_armchair.notes: The most work-intensive part was meticulously recreating the Viennese cane weave on the backrest, maintaining the original pattern and tension.
a_811_armchair.image1_desc: [The A 811 model is an example of Thonet's transition from Art Nouveau ornamentation to functionalism and modernism.]
a_811_armchair.image2_desc: [Hoffmann, as a co-founder of the Wiener Werkstätte, promoted simplicity, clear forms, and high-quality craftsmanship.]

kneeler.title: Kneeler
kneeler.description: The most valuable and unique item in Paweł Michalski's collection. It is made in such an exceptional way that it would be difficult to find a manufacturer today who would undertake to recreate the piece using that technology.
kneeler.notes: This piece is preserved in almost perfect condition. The restoration involved gently cleaning the wood and protecting it with wax to not disturb the original patina.
kneeler.image1_desc: [Thonet's kneelers are not as well-known as his chairs or rocking chairs, which is why they are a collector's rarity today.]
kneeler.image2_desc: [They were popular mainly in Central Europe (Austria, Czech Republic, Poland) in the second half of the 19th and early 20th centuries.]

cradle.title: Cradle
cradle.description: Thonet designed furniture for every stage of life, and the bentwood cradles are the best example of this. Their airy, lightweight construction and flowing lines made them not only functional but also beautiful. Often decorated with intricate details, they were an ornament in a child's room.
cradle.notes: Recreating the missing, small decorative elements required precise bending of thin beech wood strips. The structure was reinforced in inconspicuous places.
cradle.image1_desc: [Thonet cradles are rare pieces, often valued on the antiques and design market—their value reaches thousands of euros/dollars La Maison London.]
cradle.image2_desc: [Today they are rare and valued collector's items that can be considered miniature functional sculptures—a perfect example of timeless design.]
cradle.image3_desc: [One of them is even in the collection of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York The Museum of Modern Art.]

hall_tree.title: Hall Tree (Coat Stand)
hall_tree.description: Thonet's coat stands and hall trees are the quintessence of functionality and elegance. The bent wood created organic, almost sculptural forms that were a practical place for outerwear, hats, and umbrellas. They were an essential element of cafes and home hallways.
hall_tree.notes: The most important task was to stabilize the structure and repair cracks on the main supporting elements. The original dark polish was preserved, with only minor defects being filled in.
hall_tree.image1_desc: [Thonet's coat stands are often decorated with elaborate Art Nouveau elements—especially in the upper part, where bent shapes form elegant whiplash curves, consistent with the Art Nouveau aesthetic Country French Interiors 1stDibs.]

cafe_table.title: Cafe Table
cafe_table.description: Alongside chairs, cafe tables were one of the pillars of Thonet's success. They were characterized by a cast-iron, ornate base and a top made of marble or bent wood. Their construction was extremely stable and durable, ideal for intensive use in public spaces.
cafe_table.notes: The marble top required professional cleaning and polishing to remove years of stains and scratches. The cast-iron base was cleaned and protected against corrosion.
cafe_table.image1_desc: [Thonet's cafe tables, along with Chair No. 14, created the visual identity of the Viennese coffee house at the end of the 19th century.]

dataScope.title: Scope and Type of Data Collected
dataScope.content: We only collect minimal data necessary for the proper functioning of the site. This includes: language and theme preferences (saved in the browser's 'localStorage') and information about the display of the welcome popup (saved in 'sessionStorage'). We do not collect personal data such as name, surname, or email address.

dataPurpose.title: Purpose of Data Processing
dataPurpose.content: Data is processed solely to provide basic site functionality, such as remembering the selected language and graphic theme, to improve the user experience. It is not used for marketing purposes or shared with third parties.

cookies.title: Cookies and Storage Technologies
cookies.content: The site uses the browser's 'localStorage' and 'sessionStorage' technologies, which function similarly to cookies, but the data is not sent to the server. They are used exclusively to store user-side settings and do not track user activity.

dataRetention.title: Data Retention Period
dataRetention.content: Data in 'localStorage' (language, theme) is stored until manually deleted by the user in their browser settings. Data in 'sessionStorage' (welcome popup status) is automatically deleted when the browser tab is closed.

userRights.title: User Rights
userRights.content: Since we do not collect personal data, traditional rights (access, rectification, erasure) do not directly apply. The user has full control over the data stored in their browser and can delete it at any time using their browser's settings.

technological-revolution.title: The Technological Revolution: Steam-Bending Wood
technological-revolution.p1: Before Michael Thonet entered the scene, furniture production was the domain of artisans, and complex, curvilinear shapes were achieved through tedious carving and joining many small pieces of wood. It was an expensive, time-consuming, and material-intensive process, making elegant furniture a luxury available only to a few.
technological-revolution.p2: Thonet, with his vision and determination, changed this paradigm. His brilliant innovation—the technology of bending solid beech wood using steam—was a true breakthrough. The process involved subjecting carefully selected wooden rods to hot steam until they became plastic and malleable. Then, using metal forms and human muscle power, the wood was bent into elegant, fluid shapes that were previously unattainable without carving.
technological-revolution.p3: After being given the desired shape, the components were dried, causing them to harden and permanently retain their new form. This method not only drastically reduced production time but also minimized material waste and increased the furniture's strength by eliminating weak points at the joints. It was this technology that allowed for the creation of lightweight yet incredibly durable structures, such as the legendary Chair No. 14.
technological-revolution.p4: Thonet's revolution was not limited to the bending process itself. He also introduced the principles of standardization and mass production. Furniture was designed as a set of a few repeatable, interchangeable components that could be mass-produced and then easily assembled. This pioneering 'flat-pack' approach allowed for efficient transportation and distribution of furniture on an unprecedented scale, laying the foundations for the modern furniture industry.

design-democratization.title: Design Democratization: Beauty for All
design-democratization.p1: Michael Thonet's greatest social achievement was wresting good design from the hands of the elite. In the 19th century, beautiful, well-made furniture was synonymous with wealth. Thonet's industrial revolution completely changed this dynamic, introducing the concept that aesthetics and functionality need not be expensive.
design-democratization.p2: Thanks to wood-bending technology and the standardization of components, production costs dropped dramatically. A chair that would have previously required weeks of an artisan's labor could now be produced in a much shorter time by factory workers. This efficiency translated directly into the final price. Suddenly, elegant chairs, tables, and coat racks became accessible to the growing middle class, café owners, restaurants, and offices.
design-democratization.p3: The 'flat-pack' concept was another stroke of genius. Chair No. 14, consisting of just six components, two nuts, and ten screws, could be shipped disassembled in a compact crate. A single cubic meter could hold as many as 36 disassembled chairs. This minimized transportation and storage costs, enabling the export of Thonet's furniture worldwide at affordable prices.
design-democratization.p4: Thus, Thonet furniture became ubiquitous. It graced famous Viennese cafés, Parisian bistros, London offices, and middle-class homes from America to Japan. Michael Thonet proved that mass production did not have to mean compromising on quality or aesthetics. His work was the first step toward an idea that would become a cornerstone of modern design: creating well-designed objects that enrich the daily lives of all people, not just a privileged few.

global-impact.title: Global Impact: Shaping Modern Design
global-impact.p1: Michael Thonet's influence extends far beyond the 19th century and the millions of chairs sold. His innovations in production and distribution became the bedrock upon which modern industrial design was built. Thonet's philosophy—creating products that are beautiful, functional, affordable, and mass-producible—became the holy grail for future generations of designers.
global-impact.p2: His work inspired key figures and movements in design history. Early modernist architects like Le Corbusier were fascinated by the purity of form and industrial logic of Thonet's furniture. Le Corbusier frequently featured Chair No. 14 in his interior designs, praising it for its 'nobility' and its perfect blend of elegance and utility. He famously said, 'Never was a better and more elegant design and a more precisely crafted and practical item created.'
global-impact.p3: The principles of standardization and modularity that Thonet introduced became foundational to the Bauhaus, the German design school that defined modernism. The idea of creating simple, repeatable elements that could be easily assembled is a direct continuation of Thonet's thinking. His approach to materials—harnessing the natural properties of wood to their fullest potential rather than fighting them—also became a key tenet of modernist design.
global-impact.p4: Thonet's legacy is alive today. Every piece of flat-pack furniture we assemble is an echo of his revolutionary distribution system. Every designer who strives to merge aesthetics with mass accessibility is following the path forged by this visionary from Boppard. Michael Thonet didn't just sell furniture; he sold the world on the idea that good design is a universal right, not a luxury for the few.
